Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Prof. Stephen Weber and his group at the University of Pittsburgh are studying the selective transport and/or capture of molecules using a selective molecular receptor in a matrix that is a very poor solvent. Specifically, the program devises and tests fluorous media (perfluorocarbons and other solutes and solvents that dissolve in them) as the basis for selective extractions. Improved selectivity can open up tremendous possibilities for ?managing molecules? in processes critical to analysis, purification, separations, sensors, smart materials, human health, drug delivery, and synthesis.

The work provides better understanding of Teflon-like polymers, enabling scientists and engineers to make improved films and coatings useful for measuring chemicals in the environment, in foods, in biological systems, and in industrial processes. Potential impact on new types of materials and gas separations is also significant. Specific targets include chemical ?sponges? with high selectivity for perfluorooctane sulfonate and perfluorooctanoate, environmental pollutants encountered in rivers and streams. Graduate and undergraduate students (including freshmen) involved in this work are exposed to a wide range of chemistry, providing early definition of career goals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Teflon is well known as a "non-stick" material. This is true for fried eggs in Teflon-coated pans, but it is also true at the level of molecules. Most molecules would rather be floating around in air (if they are small) or dissolved in water or oil, or stuck to soil than be surrounded by Teflon. Our research project was to take advantage of that property to attract selectively only certain types of molecules to come into a Teflon-like environment. These materials (coated particles, films) could then be used to selectively remove specific chemicals for example from the environment (to clean it up), or from a biological sample (to pull out something worth measuring like a cancer marker or a drug). But the challenges were many.

We worked with a very useful type of Teflon called Teflon AF - it can be dissolved into a liquid so it can be painted on surfaces or sprayed or coated on particles. We discovered that films of this material were very "holey" or porous at the 1-2 nanometer level. This allowed small bits of liquid potentially containing molecules that are not targeted for removal. Thus, we filled the holes with Teflon-like molecules that just fit into the 1-2 nanometer holes. These films were very nonporous.

The next step is to put molecules into the films that would attract the target molecule - like putting very small baseball gloves into the Teflon to attract baseballs well. At a more technical level, molecules that stick to other molecules well have complementary properties arrayed in a similar pattern. together well to each other. See the first figure. The problem is that molecules that are intended to capture the targets may also associate with themselves, kind of defeating the purpose. The key is to make sure that the "els" can't get to each other. We do that by sticking them to a surface of a nanoparticle. See the second figure.

We also need to figure out if putting the "el"-covered nanospheres into the Teflon AF films altered the film's properties, e.g., strength. They actually make the films stronger.

We have recenlty put films similar to this to work in a measurement of quinoline.
